Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Are offspring polymorphic species hedging their bets?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stock markets are dynamic. Therefore, investors hedge their bets by investing in multiple stocks simultaneously or dividing investments between stocks and bonds. This reduces the chance of complete loss due to a stock crash but also reduces potential gains when a stock dramatically rises. Similarly, organisms may have evolved bet hedging strategies that allow them to cope with dynamic environments. To date the evidence supporting the existence of biological bet-hedging strategies stems primarily from theoretical work. To robustly assess evidence for bet hedging in nature, this study takes advantage of a fascinating reproductive strategy, termed offspring polymorphism, in which organisms produce multiple different kinds of offspring simultaneously. This strategy can be observed across many life forms including animals (e.g. frogs) and bacteria but is especially common in plants. Investigators will test the hypothesis that seed-polymorphism plants produce one seed or offspring type that is good at surviving in dry years and one that is good at surviving in wet years. This research will help scientists gain a better understanding of how organisms cope with change. This will increase predictive power about organisms' responses to environmental change and increasing desertification. Outreach to the public will occur, and undergraduate students will be trained as part of this work.
Â 
Through the combination of an innovative field experiment and stochastic population models parameterized with long-term field and experimental data, the researchers will rigorously evaluate seed polymorphism as a bet hedging strategy in Pectocarya heterocarpa, a winter, desert annual species. P. heterocarpa is particularly suitable as it produces three visually distinct and spatially separated seed types which are easy to distinguish and count. These morphs will be sown in a natural field setting under various rain reducing shelters to examine how seeds differ in their germination timing, growth, and fitness under different rainfall regimes. The ecologists will combine this data with multi-decadal temporal and spatial demographic data on P. heterocarpa. They will then parameterize density-dependent and independent models to rigorously evaluate offspring polymorphism as a bet hedging strategy. Specifically, the density-independent model will allow researchers to find optimal seed ratios under different environmental regimes while the density-dependent models allow for an adaptive dynamics approach to find evolutionary stable seed polymorphism strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pectocarya heterocarpa (Boraginaceae) is a winter, annual plant of the Sonoran Desert which simultaneously produces multiple morphologically distinct seeds. Aerial seeds are produced by flowers that open (outcrossing) while basal seeds are produced by flowers that never open (selfing). Aerial seeds come in two forms, winged and non-winged. Winged seeds are the smallest and have webbing between the bristles that surround the seed. Non-winged seeds are the second smallest and have bristles that are not webbed. Basal seeds are the largest and typically do not have any bristles or relatively smooth. Basal seeds grow at the base of the plant, near the soil surface. They are attached firmly to the plant and are hard to remove in contrast to the aerial seeds which readily detach. Aerial seeds likely serve in colonizing new habitats while basal seeds aim to secure the clearly fertile mother site. Finally, P. heterocarpa germinates with the onset of winter rains from October to December and, depending on rainfall, flowers between February and April and dies in late March or April.

 

Here we examined germination timing in P. heterocarpa and its effect on fitness in both a greenhouse and natural field setting in Tucson Arizona. We hypothesized that P. heterocarpa is hedging its bets. Specifically, we hypothesized that the timing of seed germination differs between the different seed morphs and that this directly translates to differences in fitness or seed production. Furthermore, we expected rainfall availability in each year to influence which seed morphs will be most successful.

As predicted, we found that germination timing differs among the seed morphs. Aerial winged seeds tend to germinate the earliest followed by non-winged aerial seeds and lastly basal seeds.  Overall, the plants that have the longest growing season, assuming ample rainfall produce the most offspring. However, in years were rainfall is low, early germinants tend to suffer high mortality and thus the later germinants have the highest fitness or produce the most offspring. This is because the later germinants grow during the colder months which make up for decreased rainfall (moderate aridity).  

Interestingly we found that among the seed types, if germination timing and rainfall is similar, basal seeds produce the most offspring, followed by aerial long seeds and finally aerial winged seeds. This may be associated with the size of the seeds which is mirrored in this pattern from the largest seeds, basal seeds, to the smallest seeds, winged seeds. This makes sense from an evolutionary standpoint because those seeds which come from flowers that do not open (selfing) and thus carry the highest amount of maternal DNA receive the highest resource investment from the maternal plant.

Ultimately our research demonstrates that P. heterocarpa, and likely other seed heteromorphic species, produce multiple different seed morphs simultaneously as a bet hedging strategy. The unpredictable environmental factor that drives the evolution of this strategy in our study species appears to be variability in water availability as dictated primarily by rainfall and temperature.

Our findings are important advancements in research on organisms that produce multiple different offspring simultaneously, a pattern observed across the Tree of Life, and bet hedging as an evolutionary mode of change. Furthermore, this work helps us gain a better understanding of how organisms cope with change which is crucial for gaining any predictive power for population dynamics amidst global climate change and the increasing desertification associated with it.

We have presented our work at two national meetings (Ecological Society of America) and a couple botanical organizations (Native Plant Society, UA Herbarium Series). We have also mentored 12 students throughout this project, three of which have gone on to pursue or apply for graduate research positions themselves. Finally, we are working on translating our science for the public through an engaging animation.
